turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: How do you do it?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: It's easy, it runs in my family, take my grandfather, for example...

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: You think he really believed it?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Who knows?  It worked.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: How fast?

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: Twenty-four-five.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Shit, that's nothing, I ran twenty- two flat.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I'm supposed to be leaving on a fellowship that I worked for my entire life.  I don't even care.  I met this boy over the summer, and I, I can't see him because of this, I can't talk to him, I can't talk to my father about... I wore these clothes, I thought, I thought that if I looked right and if I acted right then someone would talk to me.  But I look awful and I feel awful, could you, could you please talk to me?  Be a little decent.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: We believe that your father operates in a large pool of cash that comes from phoney billings, phoney patients.  We've been investigating him for five years.  We believe that when they die, he takes their money.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Pardon me?

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: Look, why don't you check it out for yourself?  See if your father fits the profile.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: What's the profile?

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: Well, take a look around the house.  Is everything nice, but not too nice?  Are there lots of, uh, rugs, pieces of art, stereo equipment, uh, furniture, a lot of things bought with cash?  Does he give a lot of gifts?  Do the major items in your house cover around the nine thousand-dollar range?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You're trying to get me to say something, that's why you're telling me all of this.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: Don't let your father's business infect your life.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: How can you, how can you say that?

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: Because he's guilty.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No, no he's not.

turns.speaker: AGENT
turns.text: We have records.  We have proof.  I'm sorry to be the one to have to tell you this, but it's going to get worse.  Now, if I were you, I would take that fellowship.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Jesus.  What, I live in a palace, right?  I have guests here.

turns.speaker: AGENT SIMS
turns.text: Understanding the following rights...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Speak with my lawyer.

turns.speaker: AGENT SIMS
turns.text: So you refuse to answer my questions?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Just come down to my place of business, for god's sake.  I have people here.

turns.speaker: AGENT SIMS
turns.text: Mr Court, be aware that we will be contacting a number of your business associates...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: This evening is over.

turns.speaker: AGENT SIMS
turns.text: And your former wife.

turns.speaker: AGENT SIMS
turns.text: The, uh, Cynthia Branson estate was worth how much?  Because her family...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What family?  We never heard from them.  I sold her house for them, made them money.

turns.speaker: AGENT SIMS
turns.text: Hmmm.  Your income, Mr Court, hasn't changed substantially in seventeen years.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: AGENT SIMS
turns.text: Why would you stay so long with an operation that is so clearly not a growth enterprise?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Taking care of people isn't a growth enterprise, Mr Sims.  I hope you write that down in your report, I'd like your bosses to read it.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT
turns.text: Is it a gift for your wife?  Are you getting a set together?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, I'm not married.  It's for my daughter.

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT
turns.text: For going to school?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yeah, she won a fellowship.

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT
turns.text: Good for her.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I'll take the whole set.

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT
turns.text: Excellent.

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT
turns.text: Thanks, I like yours too.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Listen, I don't know your name, but what are you doing for lunch?

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT
turns.text: I'm sorry, but they turned down your card.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh yeah, let me give you another card.

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT
turns.text: Okay, thanks.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Keep it.

turns.speaker: ASSISTANT
turns.text: You're sure?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yeah, I don't want it.  Um, thank you very much.  You're very kind.

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: Lloyd?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Hey, sis.

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: I'm sorry. Sam had to do a new crown, we had [?], and Jason had a sore throat.  Your big graduation, and no one was there.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: It's no problem.  I called Mom and Dad in Germany; it's like they were there.

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: I hope you understand.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Hey, bad throat, huh J-man?

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: Why do you eat that stuff?  There's no food in your food.  Not too loud, the red line's there for a reason.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: How do you know how to draw the red line anyway?

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: Because it's loud enough so the neighbors don't complain, that's how come I know.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Good thing there's not a red line on you, J-man. YEAH!

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: Why can't you be his uncle and not his playmate?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Jesus Christ.  I get in a good mood.  How hard is it just to decide to be in a good mood, and then be in a good mood?

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: Gee, it's easy.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Look, I'm really sorry that Mom and Dad made you take me in. Really.  If it's such a big deal, I'll go.  But remember this, it used to be fun.  It used to be warped, twisted and hilarious, and I mean that in the best possible way, I mean it as a compliment. I mean, I'm sorry T-I-M left you.  But I am not T-I-M.

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: I was hilarious once, wasn't I?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: I still am.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You're tough, J-man.

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: He's a mess!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I'll be in my office.

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: I just washed this shirt, didn't I?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: No, no, don't go in there.

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: Forget it, forget it, it's mine, it's mine!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Hello Constance.  It's me, Lloyd... nothing, I'm just driving around... she broke up with me... what do I do?  Can't she come back?  How can I get her back?... I can't think, talk to me... I fucked up... I feel like crying... she gave me a pen.  I gave her my heart and she gave me a pen.

turns.speaker: CONSTANCE
turns.text: Lloyd, honey, just come home, okay?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I'll be home soon.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: That's unlikely.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: The movies are a good second date, you know, as a date?

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: But you never had a first date.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yes I did- I sat across from her in a mall.  We ate together.  We ate, that's eating, sharing an important physical event.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: That's not even a scam.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What's a scam?

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Going out as friends.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Then what's love?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I'm gonna call her.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Diane Court doesn't go out with guys like you.  She's a brain.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Sounds great to me, I'm going to call her, that's what's cool about her.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Brains stay with brains.  The bomb could go off and their mutant genes would form the same cliques.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Look at those eyes.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Lloyd, give it up.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Do me a favor; take a picture of me with her.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Lloyd.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: C'mon, just do it.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: C'mon Lloyd.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Please?

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: That's just so embarrassing.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Please? COREY Alright. Alright, Okay, here.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Wait for me for when I get round to the front.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Okay, I got it.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: You are such a great person Lloyd.  I'm a good person, but you are a great person.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Hang in there, man.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: See you tomorrow.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: See you.  Bye.  Bye Diane.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Did you sleep with her?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I admit nothing.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Alright, alright, alright, calm down, alright, calm down. Nothing's different.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Lloyd, listen to me.  EVERYTHING has changed.  You've had sex. No matter what you might think, nothing will ever be the same between you two.  You might be sixty.  You might be walking down the street, and you'll talk to her about something, whatever. But what you'll really be thinking is 'We had sex'.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: So, what's your point?

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: You've got to do something special.  You've got to make a statement.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Alright.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Lloyd, send her flowers, write her a letter.  Something.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I already did.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: What does it say?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Read it.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I draw the line at seven un-returned phone calls.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Lloyd, you have to understand her family is being ripped apart. Like you and she were ripped apart.  Like Joe and I were ripped apart.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: No, you're not a guy.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I am.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: The world is full of guys.  Be a man.  Don't be a guy.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: If she wants me, she can come to me.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: I don't feel anything.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: Come on, it's graduation.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Did you see what Mr Carroll wrote in my yearbook?  Well, he ridiculed me all year long, and then he writes, "You're a real live-wire, Love Mr Carroll."  Y'know, it's all so phoney.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: He wants to leave things on a good note.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Well, where Mr Carroll uses the word 'love', I look for a new word.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: Trapped in the body of a gameshow hostess.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Diane Court does not realise how good-looking she is.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: I wouldn't get my hopes up Lloyd.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: I'm sorry.  It's just you're a really nice guy, and we don't want to see you get hurt.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Lloyd is doomed.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: Meaning?

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Meaning that she made the second date a family audition, which is the kiss of death for Lloyd.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: I told him to be himself.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: He's got that nervous talking thing.  I told him not to speak.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: Lloyd, it's us.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Look at his face, he did the deed.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: You're an inspiration Lloyd; you should go on the seven hundred club or something.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: Wait a minute.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: You've got to show her respect, you've got to show her that you're not like Joe...

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: Wait a minute.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: And above all, just because this happened gives you no right whatsoever...

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: You know I just sit here listening, and you never let me talk.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: What?  I'm sorry, talk.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: I've forgotten what I was going to say... okay, okay, I remember. Let him do what he wants.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: "Dear Diane, I'll always be there for you, all the love in my heart, Lloyd."  I've never gotten a letter like this, have you?

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: I dream about it.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: I wrote sixty-three songs this year.  They're all about Joe, and I'm going to play every single one of them tonight.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I just saw Joe.  He's here.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: Well, you don't have to be so dramatic about it.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: It's too much pressure, it's not his crowd.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: What is wrong with this girl?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Hey, I know this is a strange thing to say, but maybe Diane Court really likes Lloyd.

turns.speaker: COREY
turns.text: If you were Diane Court, would you honestly fall for Lloyd?

turns.speaker: U.S. ATTORNEY
turns.text: I can't give you that.  This guy's been ripping off grandma and grandpa for seventeen years.  He's been getting it from every end.  I'd love to hear his story.

turns.speaker: COURT'S ATTORNEY
turns.text: One hundred thousand dollar fine and three months?

turns.speaker: U.S. ATTORNEY
turns.text: One hundred and twenty-five thousand and nine months.

turns.speaker: COURT'S ATTORNEY
turns.text: I can accept that.

turns.speaker: U.S. ATTORNEY
turns.text: And I want to turn the home over to the state.

turns.speaker: COURT'S ATTORNEY
turns.text: He'd like to start serving immediately.

turns.speaker: U.S. ATTORNEY
turns.text: I can put that together.

turns.speaker: COURT'S ATTORNEY
turns.text: Confirm this with my office and my client.

turns.speaker: U.S. ATTORNEY
turns.text: I'll put this past my boss

turns.speaker: COURT'S ATTORNEY
turns.text: Alright.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: Lloyd, she's being difficult.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I'm going to take out Diane Court again.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: That was a mistake.  The rain on my car is a baptism.  The new me.  Iceman, power Lloyd.  My assault on the world begins now. Believe in myself, answer to no one... You probably got it all figured out, Corey.  If you start out depressed, everything's kind of a pleasant surprise.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: Look, why don't you just call Diane again?

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: Visit her at the home.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I'm not going back there.  I don't even know who you're talking about.

turns.speaker: DC
turns.text: Lloyd, why do you have to be like this?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: 'Cause I'm a guy, I have pride.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Well, it's almost over.  We've gone to school together for three years... I might cut that part out.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Why?  It's fine.  It's nice.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Having taken a few courses at the university this year, I have glimpsed our future, and all I can say is... go back.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Ha!  Go back!  What a great line!

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You like it?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh yeah!

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I didn't think anyone would get it.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh no, no, it's... it's wonderful.   It's... no, don't worry about it.  You're very funny.  Go back, that's great!

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Alright, no more, I'm going to save it.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Ha!

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Well, it's almost over.  We've gone to school together for three years, and we've been through a lot.  But with that training out of High School gone, what's going to happen to us?  We all know what the answers are.  We want to be happy, go to college, own a car, maybe raise a family.  But what if that doesn't happen?  I have, I have to be honest though, I have all the hope and ambition in the world.  But when I think about the future, the truth is, I am really...scared.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, you have to teach me to suture this weekend.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Okay, I promise I will.  Just come here a minute, I want to show you something.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, since I'm not only your father, I'm also your friend; I had to get you two presents.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: God, that's... this is ridiculous.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Now this is the only thing your mother ever gave me that I kept. Now it's yours.  Go ahead, open it.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Oh god, I don't need all these presents.  I don't know any kid who got a car, I mean...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: They really applauded you today honey.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I was standing up there and looking at all the people, and I felt like they didn't know me.  I mean, maybe I shouldn't have taken all those courses out of school, because everybody thinks I... forget it.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, wait a minute.  Everybody thinks you're what?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Everybody thinks I'm a priss.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Diane, in a million years, you could never be a... priss.  It's all working out for you honey, don't you see?  It's all working out, just like we planned.  All the years of summer school, all the vacations you gave up, it's all working out just the way we planned...

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Stop it, stop it, stop it.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I love you dad.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I love you too honey.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I just had a phone call.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Tell me, is it bad news?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, no, just listen.  You won the Wreath  fellowship.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Are you kidding?  You're not kidding?  You're not kidding!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You won it.  You're going to study at the finest institute at England, the toughest fellowship in the country, and you won.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I won?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You're going to take a big step, a big leap, and before you do, I just want one thing from you, miss.  You stand up straight and admit you're special.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: God, I'll have to go on a plane.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: We'll worry about that later.  Now come on, tell me that you're special.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Don't do this to me. You're too good at making me nervous.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, listen to me.  You're the best in the country, don't you understand?  It's like a pyramid.  It starts out with everybody, and it narrows through your life and through everything, and all the hoopla and the competition narrows it down to one brilliant person who is so special that they celebrate you on two continents.  And it's you.  So tell me something, where's the flaw in that?  There is no flaw.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Morning honey.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, I'm so glad I went.  Goodnight.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Wait a minute.  How was Lloyd?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Lloyd was such a gentleman.  He was funny and nervous and strange, and I met people that I never would have met before, then I blew it.  I called him basic.  Can you believe I did that?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, I don't think he's really been embarrassed by it.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Goodnight.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Goodnight.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: She's not the world's greatest flyer, let me tell you.  When she was eight years old, she...

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Now why can't I tell the story?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, let me start it.  I'm flying down to Los Angeles on business, and I decide to take her on her first aeroplane.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I knew how planes flew, but I was still a little nervous.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Crash paranoia.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: So anyway, they closed the doors, and she starts to scream.  I've never in my life heard anyone scream quite like that.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: And then you got up and you told them to turn the plane around.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Which they did.  Let me finish.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Okay, I give up.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: So anyway, these two federal marshals meet the plane, and they take our address, and they ask us never to fly with 'Friendly Skies' again.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh yeah.  There was, uh, somebody on the plane worked in a recording studio, and, uh, we got this telephone call, this guy is making a sound effects record, and he'd gotten our address and he wanted to know if he could come over and record her scream.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Which they did, and every once in a while on a commercial, you can hear me scream.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Morning.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You should be.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I was irresponsible, I should have called.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You bet you should have called.  You still live at home.  Don't make me call the police at three-thirty in the morning, don't make me call hospitals.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, I'm so sorry.  I know this is a bad time.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You've always called before, always.  Now I'm not asking what you did, I just want to know that you're alright.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Do you wanna make things easier on me?  Now tell me where you were because this is, this is bullshit.  You can say anything to me, I hope you still know that.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I know that.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Lloyd?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, yes.  And I'm scared to death of what you must think of me right now.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Sit down.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Did he ever get rough with you?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, no.  But I didn't want any problems, so I decided not to sleep with him.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, maybe I shouldn't go with all that's happening to you.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You're going.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: But listen, if I had a friend in the same position, I would tell her to delay a year.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You're going.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: It doesn't feel right to me.  I, I don't even have the right luggage yet.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Bon voyage.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You're not listening to me.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Diane!  Alright, let's stop this right now.  Let's not put our energy into something ridiculous.  This isn't even smart thinking.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, why are you acting this way?  Is this because of the other morning?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Do you love him?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I like him a lot.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well listen to me.  Now, I know you like him, I know he's nothing like those frat kids you can't stand, but honey, after the excitement wears off, then what, huh?  What are you going to talk about?  What do you have in common?  You're going to be part of an international think-tank, and he's going to be kicking punching bags.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Unbelievable.  This is a nightmare.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Diane, you owe it to yourself to get on that plane with no attachments, no strings, because after you get over there, things are going to change.  People change.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, you and I have talked about this.  Lloyd and I have talked about this.  Believe me, this is well-covered territory.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Diane, I'm not asking you to sever all relations with the boy. Give him a present, here, let him know you still care.  Give him this pen.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, in a million years, I would never give him a pen.  What's wrong with having some fun?  I like him.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: 'I like him'?  Diane, I'm talking about being honest with people, being decent...

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, I love him.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: If I pick it up, we'll only get back together.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well then don't pick it up. You know what's best.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, are you okay in there?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Just finishing up in here.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What happened to you?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Dad, did you do it?  Did you take that money?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Sweetheart, no.  Don't be ridiculous.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Swear to god, I need to know the truth.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Honey!

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Swear to god.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I swear to god.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: But I found the money.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Honey, it's not what you think.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: What am I supposed to think?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Honey, about what?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You stole from them, you lied to me.  How do you think that's supposed to make me feel?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You think you know what this money is?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yes, I...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, you don't know what it is.  It's not for me.  This money's for you, for when you come back from England with honors to set you up, so you don't have to depend on anybody again.  Diane, I take better care of these people than their families do.  I care for them, I give them flowers, I feed them, I wipe their mouths...

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No, but you stole from them.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I made their lives better.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You let me believe you.  You knew you were guilty, and you let me become a part of it.  God, how... how could you...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Alright, alright.  Go ahead.  When I'm old, give me someone like me, but go ahead.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I trusted you.  I stood up in court five years ago and I picked you.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Why are you being so hateful to me?  Is this because of Lloyd?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No.  I told you everything, you lied to me.  I would have done anything for you.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: That's right, work it out.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No, I will.  I don't want to leave something out because I know I can say anything to you.  You're a liar, and a thief.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Take it easy how mad you make me, I'm the only dad you've got.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I'm so ashamed dad.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Don't say that, it's not good for you.  You're...

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You're right.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I don't know what to say to you, except goodbye.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Mom, please?

turns.speaker: MRS COURT
turns.text: Diane, I do have a history with this man, and it's not the greatest.  I see you so seldom, I'd really rather know about you.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: This is me telling you about me.

turns.speaker: MRS COURT
turns.text: You know, I don't even know if you've got a young man in your life?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I just wonder what could be more important than what's going on with dad.

turns.speaker: MRS COURT
turns.text: If we could just talk about boys everything would be so much easier.  You know, your room is always ready for you, you can always come home if... alright, what do you want me to do?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: If they ask you questions, and they probably will ask you questions, would you please say something nice about him mum? Help him?

turns.speaker: MRS COURT
turns.text: Alright.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You will?

turns.speaker: MRS COURT
turns.text: Okay.  Oh, here's Ray.  Just talk to him because when you don't, your mouth turns down.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Thank-you.  The real world.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Look at those eyes.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: No noise, no sound, no movement, nothing!  Hello, Diane?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Hi.  You called me?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah.  I read about your fellowship in the paper, and I'm very glad you called me back.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah.  I just wanted to congratulate you on your scholarship to England, and I wanted to tell you that I thought your speech was really incredible.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Whoah, what a day, huh?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah.  What a day.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Quick question - do you know who I am?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yes, we sat together at Bell's Square.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah.  You remember?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No, I read it on the message.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Okay, um, so it's Lloyd and... uh... uh... let's go out.  Do you wanna go out?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Oh, thanks, but I'm busy.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Busy?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yes.  Things are pretty hectic right now, but thanks.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Are you busy on Friday?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah, I have to help my father.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Are you busy on Saturday?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Saturday, I have some things to do around the house.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: So you're monumentally busy?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Well, not monumentally.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What about tonight then, are you going to that party at Valhere's?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Hmmm....

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Look Diane, I'm sorry, but I can't allow you to leave the country without going to Valhere's graduation party.  This gentleman, he's twenty-two, and he comes out of hiding once a year for this occasion, and he dresses up as the Lakeside rooster, and he,

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Actually, I think that I...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Y'know, you're not in England yet, you know that of course, and by the way, I want to just tell you that I lived in England for a few months,

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: No tips.  I won't give you any tips of any kind.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I'll go.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Pardon me?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I'll go.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You will?  Excellent, alright, this is great.  You will, really?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Alright.  This is really great.  Alright, we're going out. It's a date.  It's a scam.  Whatever, whatever, alright, I'll pick you up at what, eight O' clock?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Eight.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Eight. Eight O' clock.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Goodbye.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Goodbye.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Whoa.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Would you hold this for me?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: What are these?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: They're Bavarian Death style  pretzels.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Oh.  Um, would it be terrible if I wanted to go home early?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Keymaster?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah, I have to judge who can drive home and who can't. I have to keep their keys.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: So it's an honor?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: So we can finally talk?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: He does this every year?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: It's the worst job since keymaster.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Thank-you.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I hereby surrender my duties as keymaster, give me a beer.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Have a good sleep.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Bye.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Alright, this is some of the things they wrote me; "Glad I finally met you", "You always seemed nice", "Wish I could have known you more"...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Mine say stuff like "Lloyd, see you around maybe"

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Nobody knew me before tonight.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: They knew of you.  Now they know you.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah, but I feel like I fit in for the first time, you know? Like I just held them far away from me, and they did the same to me.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: That's cool then.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah.  I'm so glad we did this.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: It's just you and your dad, right?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah, but that's an old story, you don't want to hear it.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Sure I do.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Well, my parents split up when I was thirteen, and... god, I actually had to... I went into court and I had to choose between the two of them.  So I chose my dad.  It just felt safer that way, you know?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Watch out for that glass.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Thanks.  But either way it still feels...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Twisted?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You know what?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You're a great date.  I've never really gone out with someone as basic as you.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Basic.  Hmmm.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: So what's your job this summer?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Job?  Being a great date.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No, I'm serious.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: So am I. I want to see you again.  I want to see you as much as I can before you leave.  I said it.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I only have something like sixteen weeks.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Sixteen weeks is a long time.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Then call me tomorrow.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Today is tomorrow.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Then call me later.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Or, or I could always wear this one.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Boy, this is a mother dictionary.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah, I've had it forever.  I used to have this thing with marking the words that I looked up.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Nice one.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I think you should wear that.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You think so?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Mmmm.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I had a checklist in mind.  I thought that if babies were on the plane, the plane couldn't crash.  But all the babies were crying, and I thought they knew something I didn't.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: After work?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I usually have a break after the dinner service, if you want to stop by.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Won't you see me later?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I know you think my job is strange.  You don't like old people, do you?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Me?  Sure I do.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Come on.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Well, except for one thing.  I used to work at a smorgasbord, and, and the old people would flock there, and, and they loved to eat.  And they just jammed their mouths, you know?  The used to eat with their mouths open, and you know, it's just too much for me.  You get to be thinking about how short life is, and how maybe, maybe has no meaning because you wake up and you're frying burgers

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I think that's ageism, and that's, that's being prejudiced against people because they're old.  Maybe their mouths don't work as well as yours.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Really?  Um... I... well... you're really turning me around here,

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Stop by later.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Okay, bye, I will.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Okay, bye.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I'll see you there.  Bye.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You have to meet Bess.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: She's amazing.  She's ninety-three, she's a writer, and I told her about you.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Wait, wait.  You told her about me?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What did you say?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Well... just meet her.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: It's okay, everybody does that.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I just don't want it to get too heavy.  I feel really overloaded. I have this theory of convergence, that good things always happen with bad things.  But I know you have to deal with them at the same time, but I just, I mean I don't know why they have to happen at the same time, I mean, I don't know why, I just wish I could work out... Am I just babbling?  Do you know what I mean?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I just can't have any social life right now.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Don't worry about it.  We're just having coffee.  We'll be anti- social.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Be friends?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah.  With potential.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Friends with potential.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah, just keep going first, keep going around.  Get the feel of it, feel the clutch, when you put it in a little?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You know how it'll come out and feel... y'know... little more, little more... Yeah, yeah, that's right.  Go round just at first, keep it in first, just feel it.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I'm doing alright.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah.  Now, when you feel like you're confident,...

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: If you'll just maybe ease it into second.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Okay, this is important...

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Am I wrecking my car?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Yeah, a little bit.  Listen, this is important.  When you feel it start to give, put the clutch in.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Oh.  I was putting the...
